meaning-of-score-description:
Total score calculation = Readability points + Heading points + Paragraph points

  • 90 points or more: Outstanding!
  • Between 80 and 90 points: Very good!
  • Between 70 and 80 points: Not too bad
  • Between 60 and 70 points: Needs work
  • Between 50 and 60 points: Needs a lot of work
  • Under 50 points: Very bad
calculation-of-readability-points-descri:
Basic Flesch-Kincaid uses 2 variables to get a score:

  • average sentence length
  • average number of syllables per word

This calculation doesn't handle headings and bullet points very well. If there isn't a period at the end of a heading or a bullet item, it considers it to be still the same sentence.

The adjusted Flesch-Kincaid readability score considers each heading and each item in a bullet list as a separate sentence.

Points are attributed using this calculation:

  • Grade 6 or under: 60/60
  • Grade 6 to 18: points go down gradually as the grade goes up
  • Grade 18 or over: 0/60

Basic Kandel-Moles uses 2 variables to get a score:

  • average sentence length
  • average number of syllables per word

This calculation doesn't handle headings and bullet points very well. If there isn't a period at the end of a heading or a bullet item, it considers it to be still the same sentence.

The adjusted Kandel-Moles readability score considers each heading and each item in a bullet list as a separate sentence.

Points are attributed using this calculation:

  • Grade 6 or under: 60/60
  • Grade 6 to 18: points go down gradually as the grade goes up
  • Grade 18 or over: 0/60
calculation-of-heading-points-descriptio:
Because it's generally a good idea to use headings and subheadings, points are attributed based on the average number of words between each heading.

The total number of words is divided by the number of individual headings (h1, h2, h3, h4, etc.)

Points are attributed using this calculation:

  • 40 words per heading or less: 20/20
  • 200 words per heading or more: 0/20
  • Between 40 and 200 words per heading: points go down gradually as the number goes up
calculation-of-paragraph-points-descript:
Because it's generally a good idea to use paragraphs and avoid a wall of text, points are attributed based on the average number of words in each paragraph.

The total number of words is divided by the number of paragraphs

Points are attributed using this calculation:

  • 30 words per paragrah or less: 20/20
  • 80 words per paragraph or more: 0/20
  • Between 30 and 80 words per paragraph: points go down gradually as the number goes up

improving-web-readability-description:
To improve web readability, follow web writing best practices, like:

  • use simple words
  • write short sentences and paragraphs
  • use subheadings and lists to help people scan the page

Follow the Canada.ca Content Style Guide

kpi-calls-per-100-tooltip: The ratio of calls received by the CRA per 100 visits to the CRA pages on Canada.ca in the reporting time period.
kpi-calls-per-100-guidance:
What is this?
The ratio of calls the CRA receives per 100 visits to the CRA pages.
The target for this Key performance indicator (KPI) is a decrease in calls per 100 visits.

How is this KPI calculated?
A: The total number of calls received by the CRA for the selected date range
B: The total number of visits to the CRA page for the selected date range

(A/B)*100

View more call drivers data
kpi-calls-per-100-tooltip-task: The ratio of calls received by the CRA per 100 visits to the pages related to this Task in the reporting time period.
kpi-calls-per-100-guidance-task:
What is this?
The ratio of calls the CRA receives per 100 visits to the pages related to this Task.
The target for this Key performance indicator (KPI) is a decrease in calls per 100 visits.

How is this KPI calculated?
A: The total number of calls received by the CRA for the selected date range
B: The total number of visits to the CRA pages related to this Task for the selected date range

(A/B)*100
kpi-calls-per-100-tooltip-project: The ratio of calls received by the CRA per 100 visits to the pages related to this UX project in the reporting time period.

kpi-feedback-per-1000-tooltip: The ratio of "No" responses to "Did you find what you were looking for?" on pages with the Page feedback tool per 1000 visits on the CRA website in the reporting time period
kpi-feedback-per-1000-guidance:
What is this?
The ratio of "No" responses to "Did you find what you were looking for?" on pages with the Page feedback tool per 1000 visits to the CRA pages.

The target for this Key performance indicator (KPI) is a decrease in “no” responses per 1000 visits to the CRA pages.

How is this KPI calculated?
A: The total number of "No" responses to "Did you find what you were looking for?" on pages with the Page feedback tool for the selected date range
B: The total number of visits to the CRA page for the selected date range

(A/B)*1000

View more feedback data
kpi-feedback-per-1000-tooltip-page: The ratio of "No" responses to "Did you find what you were looking for?" on this page, if Page feedback tool available, per 1000 visits to it in the reporting time period
kpi-feedback-per-1000-guidance-page:
What is this?
The ratio of "No" responses to "Did you find what you were looking for?" on pages with the Page feedback tool per 1000 visits to the CRA pages.

The target for this Key performance indicator (KPI) is a decrease in “no” responses per 1000 visits to the CRA pages.

How is this KPI calculated?
A: The total number of "No" responses to "Did you find what you were looking for?" on this page if the Page feedback tool is available, for the selected date range
B: The total number of visits to this CRA page for the selected date range

(A/B)*1000

kpi-search-assessment-tooltip: Search assessment performance of the top English and French search terms on canada.ca and their corresponding target URL.
kpi-search-assessment-guidance:
What is this?
Percentage of search terms that passed the search assessment.

A search term passes the assessment when its target URL is in the top 5 search results when visitors search for that term. Otherwise, it fails the search assessment.

The assessment is conducted weekly for the top 100 English and 100 French search terms.

The target for this Key performance indicator is 80%.

How is this KPI calculated?
A: The total number of search terms that have “passed”
B: The total number of search terms

(A/B)*100


View more search analytics data
kpi-ux-test-tooltip: Average success rate of the latest testing on all complete UX tests with Validation test type
kpi-ux-test-guidance:
What is this?
The percentage of average success rate for the latest testing on all complete UX tests with Validation test type.
The target for this Key performance indicator is 80%.

How is this KPI calculated?
A: The sum of latest user test success rates (in percentages) of all complete UX tests with the Validation test type
B: The total number of complete tests performed with the Validation test type

A/B
kpi-ux-test-success-all-title: Average success rate of all tasks
kpi-ux-test-success-all-tooltip: Average success rate of all tasks
kpi-ux-test-success-all-guidance:
What is this?
The percentage of average success rate for all tasks, using the latest success rate from their most recent UX test. Note: Not all tasks have been tested.
The target for this Key performance indicator is 80%.

How is this KPI calculated?
A: The sum of success rates of the most recent tasks tested
B: Total number of tasks tested

A/B
kpi-ux-test-improved-title: Average success rate of improved tasks
kpi-ux-test-improved-tooltip: Average success rate of all improved tasks
kpi-ux-test-improved-guidance:
What is this?
The percentage of average success rate for improved tasks from their latest validation UX test. It also measures improvement by comparing the average success rate of previous UX tests (baseline) with the most recent UX tests (validation).
The target for this Key performance indicator is 80%.

How is this KPI calculated?
A: The sum of validation success rates on all improved tasks
B: Total number of tasks tested

A/B

Improvement is the difference between this average success rate and the average success rate of the same tasks from their baseline tests.
kpi-ux-test-top50-title: Average success rate of top 50 tasks
kpi-ux-test-top50-tooltip: Average success rate of tasks ranked in the top 50 based on performance metrics from the previous quarter
kpi-ux-test-top50-guidance:
What is this?
This KPI measures the average success rate of tasks ranked in the top 50 from the previous quarter. It includes only improved tasks, which have both baseline and validation UX tests. It also measures improvement by comparing the average success rate of previous UX tests (baseline) with the most recent UX tests (validation) for these tasks.
The target for this Key performance indicator is 80%.

How is this KPI calculated?
A: The sum of success rates for all improved top 50 tasks in the latest validation tests
B: Total number of improved tasks tested

A/B

Improvement is the difference between this average success rate and the average success rate of the same tasks from their baseline tests.
404-message:
Something went wrong and we couldn't load the data.

calldrivers-notification: This report presents call topic results for the main agent queues based on a random sample of calls.
about-upd-desc: Providing a window into how people are interacting with the CRA online.
behind-data-desc-1: The UPD is a data-driven service that provides comprehensive, up-to-date analytics that track the performance of the CRA’s information services on Canada.ca.
behind-data-desc-2: This dashboard will contribute to our ongoing efforts to make data-informed design decisions, and transform how the CRA optimizes its information products and services.
work-in-progress-desc: This project is ever evolving. New features and sections have been planned and will be worked in over time.
custom-report-desc:
Create custom reports to gain detailed insights. Choose from two available options:
  • Traffic reports let you analyze website performance by customizing data granularity, date range, pages, metrics, and traffic dimensions.
  • Page Feedback reports focus on visitor comments to help identify areas for improvement and enhance user experience.
alert-url: Please select or add a URL
tooltip-select-date: Choose the custom date range for your report. Date selection options will change based on your chosen data granularity.
tooltip-select-granularity: Choose the granularity of your report data: None, Daily, Weekly or Monthly. This determines how data is grouped over time, affecting insights and trend identification.
tooltip-select-dimension: Choose a dimension breakdown to segment selected metrics, offering deeper insights. This breakdown can help in identifying specific patterns and behaviors.
select-pages-modal:
Choose specific pages to include in your report. Options are:

  • Paste page URLs using comma or semicolon-separated values or new lines.
  • Select from a table of all CRA pages on Canada.ca.
  • Select Task(s) to add all associated pages.
  • Select UX Project(s) to add all associated pages.
Enter URLs: Enter/Paste URLs separated by comma, semicolon or new lines

fun-fact-01: The first website was created in 1991, and now there are over 1.7 billion websites on the internet.
fun-fact-02: The most visited website in the world is Google, receiving over 60 billion visits per month.
fun-fact-03: The average website is visited for less than a minute – talk about speed browsing!
fun-fact-04: A single website can use data from over 75 different sources, like social media feeds and weather updates.
fun-fact-05: The largest website by data size is the Wayback Machine, which archives billions of webpages.
fun-fact-06: Websites track over 2.5 quintillion bytes of user data every day, enough to fill millions of DVDs.
fun-fact-07: Around 40% of visitors will leave a website if it takes more than 3 seconds to load.
fun-fact-08: WordPress powers over 35% of all websites on the internet, making it the most popular website platform.
fun-fact-09: Over 50% of website traffic comes from mobile devices, emphasizing the need for mobile-friendly design.
fun-fact-10: The average website uses 21 different cookies to track user data and preferences.
fun-fact-11: Over 500 new websites are created every minute, adding to the vast expanse of the internet.
fun-fact-12: Websites with video content can increase user engagement by up to 80%.
fun-fact-13: The top three most used fonts on websites are Arial, Helvetica, and Times New Roman.
fun-fact-14: Each Canadian internet user generates about 1.5 terabytes of data yearly, from emails to online gaming.
fun-fact-15: Global data storage capacity soared from 2.6 exabytes in 1986 to 295 exabytes in 2007.
fun-fact-16: The world's fastest supercomputers can perform over a hundred quadrillion calculations per second.
fun-fact-17: Data visualization is key, as humans process visuals 60,000 times faster than text.
fun-fact-18: By 2025, over 75 billion IoT devices worldwide will generate enormous data volumes.
fun-fact-19: Canada enforces strict data privacy laws like PIPEDA to regulate businesses handling personal information.
fun-fact-20: Every day, mobile devices around the world generate about 18.9 billion text messages.
fun-fact-21: Cloud computing services are expanding rapidly, expected to exceed a $300 billion industry by 2024.
fun-fact-22: The GPT in ChatGPT stands for 'Generative Pre-trained Transformer,' highlighting its ability to generate text.
fun-fact-23: Self-driving cars powered by AI can make over 20 million calculations per second to ensure safe driving.

gc-tasks-modal-text:
The GC Task Success Survey measures the performance of the Government of Canada web presence for visitors in three ways: task success, ease and satisfaction.
The survey helps center our work on visitor needs by:
  • measuring how effectively digital content is serving visitor needs
  • receiving comments from visitors about their experience
  • identifying areas to prioritize for improvement
Description of the main indicators in this survey:

Task completion
This is the percentage of respondents that said they were able to complete the purpose of their visit. This is calculated by dividing the number of completed responses who answered “Yes” in question 3 by all completed responses.

Ease
This is the percentage of respondents that said it was 'easy' or 'very easy' to do what they needed to do online. This is calculated by dividing the number of completed responses who answered “Easy” OR “Very easy” in question 2 by all completed responses.

Satisfaction
This is the percentage of respondents that said they were 'satisfied' or 'very satisfied' with their experience on the website. This is calculated by dividing the number of completed responses who answered “Satisfied” OR “Very satisfied” in question 1 by all completed responses.

Margin of Error
We use margin of error in this report as we are interested in metrics for the entire population of Canada.ca visitors, but it is not possible to measure everyone in that population. Therefore, we survey a smaller sample of the population and can then estimate the true score of a given metric based on the sample results.
The margin of error tells us how many percentage points our results will differ from the real population values, based on a 95% confidence interval. In other words, it tells us how good our predictions of the online experience indicators are expected to be.
For example, a 4% margin of error means that our statistic will be within 4 percentage points of the real population value 95% of the time.

It is important to note that we have displayed the average of the margins of error for the three online experience indicators (task completion, ease, satisfaction) for ease of understanding.

Data reliability
This column in the report tells you how reliable the data is, based on the margin of error. Data with a higher margin of error is less reliable, as we are less confident that the observed scores from the samples are reflective of the true scores of the entire population. The margin of error tends to get less reliable as the sample size gets smaller or the variability of the sample increases.
The thresholds for data reliability are as follows:
  • 'Low margin of error/Reliable data' represents a margin of error less than 5%.
  • 'Higher margin of error/Use data with caution' represents a margin of error less than 10%.
  • 'Insufficient data' represents a margin of error greater than or equal to 10%.
If the margin of error is greater than or equal to 10%, data for the online experience indicators has not been provided.

More info about GC Task Success Survey
tooltip-gc-tasks-average-completion: The average completion score for GC Task Success Survey participants
tooltip-gc-tasks-average-ease: The average ease score for GC Task Success Survey participants
tooltip-gc-tasks-average-satisfaction: The average satisfaction score for GC Task Success Survey participants
tooltip-improvement-comment: Comment for the 'How could we have created a better experience for you?' question, after the respondents answer 'Yes' to 'Were you able to complete what you came to do?'
tooltip-notcomplete-comment: Comment for the 'Why weren't you able to complete what you came to do?' question, after the respondents answer 'No' to 'Were you able to complete what you came to do?'
tooltip-grouping: Grouping or clustering of the comments as a list of main keywords
tooltip-survey-volume: Total number of GC Task Success Survey respondents that selected the corresponding task as the main reason for their CRA website visit
tooltip-self-reported-success: Percentage of GC Task Success Survey respondents that said they were able to complete the purpose of their visit for the corresponding task
tooltip-latest-success-rate: Average task success from last UX test (Baseline or Validation)
flow-guidance:
What does this feature do?

The "Traffic flow" feature allows you to explore how users interact with a specific page on canada.ca website.

Why use it?

The "Traffic flow" feature helps analyze user navigation patterns by visualizing the pages users visit before and after a Focus page. Use it to:

  • Optimize content and navigation: Understand how users arrive at and leave the Focus page to improve their experience.
  • Enhance task completion: Identify and address pain points in the user journey by combining this analysis with other reports and metrics.

How you can use it?

  • View previous and next pages: On the left side, "Previous top pages visited" displays the top pages users visited before the Focus page, along with their visits and percentage of total Focus page visits. On the right side, "Next top pages visited" shows the top pages users visited after the Focus page, along with their visits and percentage of total Focus page visits.
  • Select previous and next pages: Click on a page in the Previous or Next lists to add it to the flow. The selected page will be added to the left (for previous pages) or right (for next pages) of the Focus page. The flow can include up to 5 pages, including the Focus page.
  • Understand flow metrics: Visits represent the number of times a page was part of the navigation flow.
    Rank indicates the page’s position in the top pages list.
    Entries and Exits represent the percentage of visits starting or ending at the page in the flow.
  • Reset the flow: Clicking "Reset" clears the selected pages in the specific list and restores the default view.
  • Load more data: Use "Load more" to expand the lists and view additional pages for analysis.
flow-limit: You've reached the limit of 5 pages, including the Focus page, to be displayed in the flow.
flow-select-previous: Select a previous page from the list below
flow-select-next: Select a next page from the list below
flow-tooltip-top-prev-nopages: The list below consists of the top pages that users visited prior to the focus page {{ focuspage }}
flow-tooltip-top-prev: The list below consists of the top pages that users visited prior to the page {{ page }}, following the existing page flow to the focus page {{ focuspage }}
flow-tooltip-top-next-nopages: The list below consists of the top pages that users visited after the focus page {{ focuspage }}
flow-tooltip-top-next: The list below consists of the top pages that users visited after the focus page {{ focuspage }}, following the existing page flow to the page {{ page }}
flow-tooltip-flow-prev: In the selected flow to the focus page, {{ visits }} visits included {{ page }} page at some point before reaching the focus page, by following the selected pages in the flow.
flow-tooltip-flow-prev-beforefocus: In the selected flow to the focus page, {{ visits }} visits included {{ page }} page before reaching the focus page.
flow-tooltip-flow-next: In the selected flow from the focus page, {{ visits }} visits included {{ page }} page at some point after leaving the focus page, by following the selected pages in the flow.
flow-tooltip-flow-next-afterfocus: In the selected flow from the focus page, {{ visits }} visits included {{ page }} page after leaving the focus page.
disclaimer-versioning: The "Version history" feature displays changes made to pages since June 2023, with version dates indicating when changes were detected rather than when they went live; discrepancies of up to a week may occur.
tooltip-versioning: Compare different versions of this page to track changes over time.
guidance-versioning:
The "Version history" feature displays changes made to pages since June 2023, with version dates indicating when changes were detected rather than when they went live; discrepancies of up to a week may occur.

What does this feature do?

The "Version history" feature allows you to track changes made to a webpage over time.

Why use it?

This feature helps you monitor updates and modifications made to the page content, and it also allows you to track changes in text, links, hidden elements, and modal/pop-ups over time. This can help identify or confirm updates impacting the user experience or information clarity.

How to use it?

  • Select a previous version from the dropdown.
  • Compare it with the current version (or another version).
  • Choose a view mode:
    • Web Page: See the rendered page with changes highlighted.
    • Page Source: View the raw HTML changes.
  • Navigate through and review the changes using the legend below:
  •   Previous version
  •   Updated version
  • Updated links
  •   Hidden content
  •   Content displayed in a modal/pop-up
  •   Content that loads after the initial page load.

Note: The live preview may not fully reflect pages where certain content loads dynamically after the page opens. This may include content loaded by AJAX using separate JSON files. To ensure you see the most up-to-date version, please visit the live webpage.
total-changes: Total: {num, plural, one {# change} other {# changes}}
no-comparison-available: This page has no previous versions available for comparison. Version tracking starts when updates are detected, so new or unchanged pages may not have comparison data.
no-pageversion-changes: No content, only code changes. Check Page source.
accessibility-description: Test this page for WCAG 2.1 AA compliance using automated accessibility checks.
accessibility-score-tooltip: Overall accessibility score based on WCAG 2.1 AA criteria
accessibility-tested-at-tooltip: When this accessibility test was performed
accessibility-total-automated-tooltip: Number of tests that can be verified by machines
accessibility-failed-tests-tooltip: Accessibility issues detected by automated testing
accessibility-manual-checks-tooltip: Tests that MUST be verified by human testers
accessibility-automated-limitation: Note: Automated testing can only detect approximately 30% of accessibility issues. Manual testing with assistive technologies is essential for comprehensive accessibility compliance.
accessibility-failed-description: These are accessibility issues that automated testing has detected and must be fixed to meet WCAG 2.1 AA standards.
accessibility-passed-description: These accessibility requirements have been successfully verified by automated testing. Remember, this represents only about 30% of total accessibility requirements.
accessibility-manual-description: These aspects CANNOT be verified by automated tools and require human testing with assistive technologies (screen readers, keyboard navigation, etc.)
accessibility-not-applicable-description: These audits don't apply to the current page, often because the page doesn't contain the relevant elements (e.g., video-related audits when no videos are present).
accessibility-all-tests-passed: All automated accessibility tests passed. Remember that automated testing can only detect about 30% of accessibility issues - manual testing is still required.
accessibility-manual-interactive-control: Custom interactive controls are keyboard focusable and display a focus indicator. [Learn how to make custom controls focusable](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/lighthouse/accessibility/focusable-controls).
accessibility-manual-interactive-element: Interactive elements indicate their purpose and state

Interactive elements, such as links and buttons, should indicate their state and be distinguishable from non-interactive elements. [Learn how to decorate interactive elements with affordance hints](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/lighthouse/accessibility/interactive-element-affordance/).
accessibility-manual-logical-tab: The page has a logical tab order
accessibility-manual-logical-tab-descrip: Tabbing through the page follows the visual layout. Users cannot focus elements that are offscreen. [Learn more about logical tab ordering](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/lighthouse/accessibility/logical-tab-order/).
accessibility-manual-dom-order: Visual order on the page follows DOM order
accessibility-manual-dom-order-descripti: DOM order matches the visual order, improving navigation for assistive technology. [Learn more about DOM and visual ordering](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/lighthouse/accessibility/visual-order-follows-dom/).
accessibility-manual-focus-trap: User focus is not accidentally trapped in a region
accessibility-manual-focus-trap-descript: A user can tab into and out of any control or region without accidentally trapping their focus. [Learn how to avoid focus traps](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/lighthouse/accessibility/focus-traps/).
accessibility-manual-new-content: The user's focus is directed to new content added to the page
accessibility-manual-new-content-descrip: If new content, such as a dialog, is added to the page, the user's focus is directed to it. [Learn how to direct focus to new content](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/lighthouse/accessibility/managed-focus/).
accessibility-manual-html5-landmark: HTML5 landmark elements are used to improve navigation
accessibility-manual-html5-landmark-desc: Landmark elements (<main>, <nav>, etc.) are used to improve the keyboard navigation of the page for assistive technology. [Learn more about landmark elements](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/lighthouse/accessibility/use-landmarks/).
accessibility-manual-offscreen-content: Offscreen content is hidden from assistive technology
accessibility-manual-offscreen-content-d: Offscreen content is hidden with display: none or aria-hidden=true. [Learn how to properly hide offscreen content](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/lighthouse/accessibility/offscreen-content-hidden/).
accessibility-manual-custom-control-desc: Custom interactive controls have associated labels, provided by aria-label or aria-labelledby. [Learn more about custom controls and labels](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/lighthouse/accessibility/custom-controls-labels/).
accessibility-manual-aria-roles-descript: Custom interactive controls have appropriate ARIA roles. [Learn how to add roles to custom controls](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/lighthouse/accessibility/custom-control-roles/).
core-web-vitals-description: Test this page's Core Web Vitals to measure real-world user experience metrics for loading performance, interactivity, and visual stability.
core-web-vitals-performance-score-toolti: Overall performance score from Google PageSpeed Insights (0-100). Higher scores indicate better performance.
core-web-vitals-no-data: No Core Web Vitals data available
core-web-vitals-description-detailed: Core Web Vitals are a set of real-world, user-centered metrics that quantify key aspects of the user experience. They measure dimensions of web usability such as load time, interactivity, and the stability of content as it loads.
core-web-vitals-impact-seo: Google uses them as ranking signals for search results
core-web-vitals-standardized: They provide standardized metrics for measuring real-world performance
core-web-vitals-lab-data-note: Note: Lab data (like from PageSpeed Insights) provides estimates based on simulated conditions. Real user data may vary based on actual devices, networks, and user behavior.
